text: hello this is chef john from
foodwishes.com
with
southern style slow cooked green beans
that's right why in the world would we
take something that normally takes five
minutes to cook and cook it for two
hours because it produces one of the
most delicious things you'll ever taste
and while it may seem crazy to quote
unquote overcook green beans this long
one taste of these and you'll realize
it's actually crazy not to so let me
show you how to make these just in case
you have the courage to try them all
right step one i'm going to take a
saucepan and place it on medium heat
we're going to throw in one handful of
sliced bacon because this is a southern
inspired recipe i'm using the southern
units of measure so one handful of bacon
and we're going to cook that on medium
heat until it's almost crisp we don't
want it super dark brown but we want it
almost crispy all right so give it a
stir once in a while and while that's
working we might as well slice up our
onion that's just good time management
so i have yellow onion that i peeled and
cut in half and we're going to slice it
but not across the grain
we usually go that way but we're going
to turn it and cut in the same
directions as those lines and by cutting
the onion in the same direction that the
fibers that hold the onion together go
those pieces are actually going to hold
their shape better and they won't just
all disappear but having said that you
slice it in any fashion you see fit you
are the tim gun of your onion so we're
going to slice up an onion by this time
the bacon should be pretty much ready
which it is it'll look like that all
right sometimes we drain the bacon fat
and sometimes we don't and this time
we don't all right so just leave that
fat in there we can skim that off later
if we want we're going to go ahead and
throw in our onion and then you know
what's going to happen the salt in the
bacon is going to pull moisture out of
the onion which in turn is going to
deglaze the bottom and those onions are
going to get all soft and sweet and
golden brown so we're going to cook that
stirring that's going to probably take
about five minutes for that to happen
and once it does let's go ahead and
throw in some minced garlic
all right couple cloves give that about
a one minute stir you know the drill we
don't want to brown the garlic
and then we're going to throw in just a
touch of tomato so i'm just using like a
quarter cup of tomato sauce you could
use chopped fresh tomato
in fact i encourage it or pretty much
any tomato product and we'll give that a
stir
and that pot right there is ready for
the green beans
and there we go i have about two pounds
of regular adult green beans don't use
those little skinny french ones those
are nice for some things but not this
and these are fully trimmed the ends
have been cut off
and we'll go ahead and add those to the
pot and once the beans go in we're going
to add some liquid
i'm going to add chicken stock you could
certainly use water or a combination
at this point you can raise the heat to
high and while we're waiting for that to
come up to a simmer let's go ahead and
add a little seasoning
we're gonna add some freshly ground
black pepper
some cayenne and a pinch of salt
and we'll adjust the salt later you just
want to pinch at this point the bacon
has salt in it of course
so we're gonna season that up and as
this comes up to temperature the beans
will lose their rigidity and they'll
kind of slump down into that stock
and you'll see as it starts to boil the
liquid levels should be right up to the
top of the beans and at this point we're
going to turn our heat down to medium
low
and we just want to maintain a steady
simmer all right so we don't want it too
low we do want some bubbles but we don't
want a rolling boil either so somewhere
in between we call that the goldilocks
simmer and then all you're going to do
is let that simmer for two hours i know
it sounds crazy but it's not crazy at
all give it a gentle stir once in a
while
and that's really all you have to do of
course you will monitor your liquid
level if it seems like it's getting low
you'll add a splash of stock or water
and on the other hand after two hours if
it seems like there's too much liquid
just raise your heat and reduce a little
bit now one thing i do like to do at
about the one and a half hour mark i
will give a little taste for salt i
added a little pinch here
and yes if you want to is it simmering
you can skim off a little bit of that
bacon fat or as my friends in the south
would tell you don't so anyway you're
simply going to stew those beans for
that crazy long cooking time and after
two hours you're going to have yourself
a pot of the softest
tenderest sweetest most succulent
gorgeous green beans you've ever tasted
in your life so right there mine were
just absolutely perfect look at that i
don't even mind the color i think those
are gorgeous so we're going to spoon
those up on a serving platter make sure
you're using something kind of deep
something with a rim there's going to be
a lot of juice that's what you dip your
cornbread into oh yeah i've said it
before and i'll say it again people down
south they know how to eat all right so
we're gonna put that on a plate there's
no need for garnish just start eating
and seriously if you like green beans in
their bright green crisp tender state
force yourself to give these a try it is
an entirely different and new and
exciting green bean experience i mean i
love pink medium rare steak but that
doesn't mean i don't eat stew once in a
while so yes this is a recipe video but
it's really a little more than that it's
about not being a slave to conventional
wisdom and always cooking things the
same way i love a quick stir-fried green
bean side dish but i also love this and
to be honest i like this way more so i
really do hope you give that a try head
over to foodwishes.com for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
